message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient meets the criteria for Schizophreniform disorder, which includes a duration of symptoms of at least one month but less than six months. The presence of delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and flat affect are consistent with a diagnosis of Schizophreniform disorder. Schizophrenia requires symptoms to last at least six months. Schizoaffective disorder includes both mood disorder and psychotic symptoms, which are present in this patient. Schizotypal personality disorder refers to a long-standing pattern of odd beliefs and behaviors, but does not include the presence of delusions or hallucinations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Schizophreniform disorder, which is diagnosed when the patient presents with symptoms of schizophrenia but has not met the full criteria for diagnosis, which requires the symptoms to be present for at least 6 months. Schizophrenia requires symptoms to be present for 6 months or longer. Schizoaffective disorder requires the patient to have an affective episode during the active phase of symptoms, and thus does not fit this patient’s presentation. Schizotypal personality disorder involves long-term patterns of odd or eccentric behavior and difficulty with social relationships, but typically lacks the presence of delusions, hallucinations, or disorganized speech.

Schizotypal personality disorder shares some symptoms with schizophrenia, but it is not characterized by delusions or hallucinations.
